stream_context.summary: Kaze works on Course 15’s ‘space city’ graphics and begins formal design of the world-ending boss fight set in the factory/rocket area. Half the stream is shader and texture experiments for a reflective skyscraper wall; the other half is a live design session for a mutated-Yoshi boss and its arena.

development_findings.summary: Replaced entire space-city graphic set within a week after deeming the previous look ‘ugly’. Kaze now targets a darker palette with large, slow-moving star reflections on building walls.
development_findings.quote: I realized it’s ugly and I changed the whole graphics again.

development_findings.summary: Experiments with reflection use i4 vs i8 textures; i4 causes visible banding, so an i8 64×64 star tile combined with additive combiner settings is chosen.
development_findings.quote: I think the reason it’s so bad is because we use an i4 texture… i4 only has 16 sub-steps, so you see all this colour banding.

development_findings.summary: Final wall effect uses a square-grid star texture provided by community member Asa and a custom combiner formula (Texture0 × Alpha + Shade).
development_findings.quote: That’s way nicer than what I had before, but why?

development_findings.summary: Engine optimisations let the hack run in 480i; Kaze claims other N64 titles could reach the mode if his optimisations were applied.
development_findings.quote: If you were to apply my optimisations to Ocarina 64 obviously you would be able to run it at 480i modes without too much trouble.

development_findings.summary: Course 15 boss will be a gigantic, mutated Yoshi that teleports via black holes and attacks with tongues, acid puddles, shockwaves, and rolling ‘egg’ spins.
development_findings.quote: Big mutated Yoshi… he has three tongues that all come out and you have to jump on his tongue like Gooper Blooper.

development_findings.summary: Damage concept pivots from killing the monster to ‘healing’ it: Mario destroys pulsating tumours/energy cells on Yoshi’s back, restoring normal colour and personality.
development_findings.quote: What if you just destroy the tumours and that makes him happy and he’s like ‘Wow, thanks for helping me.’

development_findings.summary: Arena concept evolves into a large hexagon-style factory floor with low-gravity zones and falling acid; boss speed decreases as Mario gets directly behind it.
development_findings.quote: The larger the angle behind him, the slower he should get so you aren’t stuck.

development_findings.summary: Smaller enemies will be baby mutant Yoshis with single growths; punching them cures them and earns coins, teaching the boss mechanic.
development_findings.quote: The baby Yoshis teach you to kill the growths.

development_findings.summary: Kaze rejects adding mech suits or major ability changes, aiming to keep standard Mario 64 physics throughout.
development_findings.quote: One important ground rule… most of the time you will stay Mario with the same physics.

development_findings.summary: Demo limited to Course 1 only so survey feedback focuses on physics and camera; additional content deliberately withheld.
development_findings.quote: Putting in more than just Course 1 distracts from the purpose… I didn’t want to reveal more than I have to.

context_findings.summary: Kaze shows visible frustration with texture work and chat suggestions, yet experiences relief when a solution is found.
context_findings.quote: Why does it have to look so bad? Ugh… Okay, maybe I do like it now.

context_findings.summary: He is anxious about his ‘second channel’ becoming too popular because streams are unfiltered and personal.
context_findings.quote: It’s too private for the public… I’m a little scared that there’s too many people watching.

context_findings.summary: Strong antipathy toward the SM64 PC port community; constant requests make him refuse to engage out of ‘pure stubbornness’.
context_findings.quote: People have been so insistent and annoying about the PC port that out of pure stubbornness I want nothing to do with it.

context_findings.summary: States design philosophy: prefers making a ‘cool N64 game’, staying within console limits and original mechanics.
context_findings.quote: I’m not in it for the money anyway. I just want to make a cool N64 game.

context_findings.summary: Mentions workout schedule and potential Thursday/Tuesday streams, hinting at balancing health and dev time.

biobak.summary: Co-developing the Course 15 boss; proposed ‘tentacle Yoshi’ with multiple tongues and provided initial concept sketch.
biobak.quote: Me and Biobak… we were thinking it should be a mutated Yoshi with like ten tongues.

key_stories.title: Cracking the Reflection
key_stories.summary: Kaze struggles for over an hour to create convincing reflective skyscraper walls. After dismissing several approaches and complaining about colour banding, community member Asa submits a square-grid star texture that finally works, leading to an immediate visual breakthrough.
key_stories.challenge: Current wall reflections looked noisy and unreadable due to low-bit textures and scrolling speed.
key_stories.process: Tried diagonal lines, smaller textures, brightness tweaks, different combiners; reviewed Dario’s earlier example; tested larger star tiles and higher-precision i8 format.
key_stories.outcome: Adopts Asa’s 64×64 star grid with custom additive combiner, achieving the desired slow, crisp reflection.
key_stories.key_quote: That’s way nicer than what I had before, but why?

key_stories.title: Pivot to Healing the Boss
key_stories.summary: Initial plan was to ‘kill’ a tentacled Yoshi boss. Mid-stream, chat pitched curing its tumours instead. Kaze embraced the idea: destroying growths heals Yoshi, who thanks Mario and departs.
key_stories.challenge: Wanted a dramatic boss encounter that fit Yoshi-centric lore without feeling cruel.
key_stories.process: Brainstormed attacks (tongues, acid, black holes), debated baby-Yoshi enemies; chat suggested a pacifist twist.
key_stories.outcome: Boss mechanic now centres on curing tumours; fight ends peacefully with star reward.
key_stories.key_quote: What if you just destroy the tumours and that makes him happy… ‘Thanks for helping me!’

key_stories.title: Refusing the PC Port
key_stories.summary: Viewers repeatedly ask Kaze to move development to the SM64 PC port or to X-coop. Kaze vents frustration, explaining he avoids it because of constant pressure and a desire to stay authentic to N64 hardware.
key_stories.challenge: Persistent community expectation that his hacks should target the PC port.
key_stories.process: Explains philosophical and technical reasons, emphasises optimisation for console, and likens the requests to being asked daily to enter Formula 1.
key_stories.outcome: Restates firm decision to keep development on N64 hardware only.
key_stories.key_quote: Even if I could see a use case, I’d still say no because everyone’s been so goddamn annoying about it.
